title: How and why is cultural relativism a threat to morality? - Quora

response.answer_text: It really isn’t. Cultural relativism isn’t a moral framework. Cultural relativism is a tool that was developed within anthropology for the purposes of better understanding cultures in as objective and unbiased way as possible. Cultural relativism doesn’t tell people how to behave in their everyday lives, it tells anthropologists how to think and behave as social scientists in order to better eliminate cultural bias and assumptions from their observations and analysis. This is sometimes misunderstood and there is something of a minor ‘moral panic’ around the idea. Some people think that cultural relativism makes morality meaningless either because: it prevents groups or individuals from passing moral judgement on each other (eg. forcing them to tolerate harmful behaviour when it occurs in a different culture)or it is the belief that morality is whatever people think it is, according to personal preference or conscience, leading effectively to moral nihilismThere actually is a philosophy which does correspond to a. which is called ‘normative ethical relativism’. This is a problematic and possibly self-defeating idea. And one that corresponds to b. called ‘moral subjectivism’ which is equally nonsensical. However, these aren’t really very widespread ideas and pose no real threat to society.

It isn’t. It’s a threat to certain conceptions of morality, which hold that moral principles have fixed, universal expressions, that we all known them whether we acknowledge them or not. And it really isn’t even much of a threat to those, because I’ve never met someone who deeply held to moral absolutism who was swayed in the slightest by deeper understandings of context. What cultural relativism is threat to is the cultural dominance of a certain type of moral thinking.

It is common for Islamists to kill their daughters for various errors. This is a cultural thing which is punished in western cultures as murder. To say no culture is better than the other is to legitimize ‘honor killings.’ This is a threat to morality.

Morality is not relative but absolute. What’s wrong now will aways and was always wrong, though certain values have evolved such as the outlawing of slavery and child labor. The Nazis used that kind of reasoning to justify themselves and were convicted at Nuremberg by natural law which is absolute. This kind of reasoning would’ve absolved them. Examples of eternal evils are murder, rape, incest, bestiality, necrophilia, pedophilia, adultery, theft, kidnapping, cannibalism, etc.).

If we accept the modernist brainwashing promoted by mass media and public higher education that ‘all morality is culturally relative’, then we stop consulting our innate sense of right and wrong. ‘Cultural relativism’ (at least as non-anthropologists understand the term) is the ultimate rationalization for committing all manner of moral error and overindulgence.
